p: Understanding cognitive processes that shape decision-making on sustainability and climate change is vital to assist companies in their transition to a low-emissions sustainable future. It has become clear through this review that these decisions challenge managers on multiple fronts, largely going against the business-as-usual operation of a firm, requiring the ambidexterity to manage potentially conflicting short- and long-term drivers. Requiring long-term investment under increasingly uncertain conditions, existing frames constructed during stable market conditions are proving insufficient to enable climate-related action (Slawinski et al., 2015). It is now time for academics to also break our own cognitive frames to consider how we cannot just promote sustainability, but a step change towards a paradigm shift in action.
